content.description: The crux is just above the first bolt. It is smooth sailing after that.
content.location: Start to the left of the 5.10d and just right of Bills in my Pockets.

content.description: Start on the right of the 5.10d. The crux of the climb is after the 3rd clip: moving into a blank section with crimps and sloper pockets. Climb 3 to 4 tough moves (depending on your height), and finish with a few easy moves to the anchor.
content.protection: Bolts and fixed anchor at the top.

content.description: This is right in the middle of the main face. The majority of the climb is 5.8 with 2 5.10d moves.
content.location: It is in the middle of the main face between the 5.9 and 5.10a.

content.description: This route begins with a few thin and pocket moves to the first bolt followed by some easy cruising to a small overhang. Move right to get over the roof on good holds. Continue right after the overhang to the anchors.
content.protection: 4 bolts and an anchor with rap chains.
content.location: This route is the farthest right bolted sport line.

content.description: Begin up the hill a little for an easier start trending to the right or go direct for the bolt for more challenge. A low crux on the steeper lower face of the climb gives way to easy climbing on the dirtier slab above.
content.location: This climb is the second from the left side. It begins just slightly up the hill from the corner at the left end of the crag.

content.description: Begin on deceptively easy pockets and holds leading to a few thin crux moves around 2/3 to 3/4 of the way up. Finish on easier moves to the anchor. Fun!
content.protection: 4 bolts and an anchor with rap chains.
content.location: This route is the 4th sport route from the right side of the crag. It begins very near to and just left of a tree.

content.description: One of the few overhanging routes at the Sunbowl, this route provides some more pumpy challenge. Begin with a little bouldery move off the deck into some brief, moderate moves. Pull through the overhanging bulge with some difficulty, but the holds are all there. Finish on an easy slab.
content.protection: Bolts (5?) and a bolt anchor with rap chains.
content.location: This is the third route from the left side of the crag. It is the left of two routes on the overhanging bulge at the left end of the Sunbowl.

content.description: This is a fairly straightforward line with some moderate crux moves after the second bolt. Begin on a technical face to join a right-curving fold. Climb over the fold through a brief crux sequence to a decent jug and easy finish. It is pretty short but enjoyable.
content.protection: 3 bolts and an anchor with rap chains.
content.location: This is the 2nd bolted sport line from the right.

climbs.name: Pocket Knife
climbs.fa: unknown, let me know, and I'll fix it

content.description:
This isn't the real name, let me know what it is, and I'll change it.

 Start by sidepulling/laybacking that big, right-angling crack in front of an oak. Do a bouldery move to the right to stand up, and clip the first bolt. Then go up bolt to a bolt. This shares the last bolt and chains with Bolsillos del Sol.
content.location: It is just right of Bolsillos del Sol and right of Bills In My Pockets.

content.description: This is a fun, basic route with a thin crux about 3/4 of the way up. It is moderate to the anchor.
content.protection: 4? bolts and an anchor with rap chains.
content.location: This is the 3rd sport line from the right end of the crag. It is located very near and just to the right of a tree.

content.description: I don't know, it's like 3 bolts or something. Go up, and stay sorta right of the bolts at first. Use pockets, pull down. If you know the actual name of this thing, let me know, and I'll change it.
content.protection: Bolts. Use your eyes, and count them.
content.location: Start right in front of the oak tree.

content.description: This ascends a rather short and dirty slab.
content.location: This route is farthest to the left, slightly up the hill.

content.description: The easier of the two overhanging buttress routes, Pockets of the Sun[bowl], begins at an obvious crack then climbs up over an overhanging bulge. Finish early at an anchor just above the overhang or continue only a few more feet to another anchor. This looks more difficult than it is from the ground. All the holds are there through the crux.
content.protection: Bolts (4?) and a bolted anchor with rap chains.
content.location: This is the fourth sport line from the left end of the crag. On the right side of the "overhang buttress", begin at an obvious crack.

content.description: This climb has variations from 5.9 to 5.11. Begin just right of a distinct crack at the base of a block. Climb up and over the crack, then trend left for the easier 5.9 variation. A pocket (or two) about 2/3 of the way up can fill with water and mud after a good rain storm, so be prepared. As Richard once said, "The dirty ones are more fun."
content.protection: 4 bolts and an anchor with rap chains.
content.location: This is the 5th climb from the left end of the cliff, around the right side of the overhang buttress. It is located immediately right of a tree and a distinct, right-trending crack.

content.description: The Sunbowl is a small craglett in Sunderland, MA. The cliff is composed of what is known as Mt. Toby Conglomerate which is a pockety hodge-podge of medium quality rock, a stark contrast to the gneiss in the region but a pleasant change. The Sunbowl hosts llitle more than a dozen routes overall, but they range from approximately 5.6 to 5.11 as well as a boulder traverse of the base of the cliff (~V2).The crag stands at about 35 feet tall overall. A slabby section on the far left gives way to a slightly overhanging buttress which then leads to a steep center face and moderate right side face. All routes are well-protected sport lines with installed rappel anchors (any climb here can be climbed with 6 or fewer draws). Due to the nature of the rock here, it is best to inspect each bolt for security upon using it. Top access at the Sunbowl is poor, so the best option is to simply lead a climb then hang a top-rope.The Sunbowl is generally southwest- facing and receives sun from at least noon onwards (hence the name). In the fall, winter, and early spring, the crag gets nice sun for warmth and in the summer is shaded well enough under the canopy of trees. A large flat rock is situated at the center of the crag and is a great staging area for gear. Remember to bring bug spray, sun screen, and sunglasses.
